Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  turns = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  params = NULL,
  seed = deprecated(),
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "text", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

turns

A list of Turns to start the chat with (i.e., continuing a previous conversation). If not provided, the conversation begins from scratch.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

API key to use for authentication.

You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable. The best place to set this is in .Renviron, which you can easily edit by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

params

Common model parameters, usually created by params().

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call. Combined with the body object generated by ellmer with modifyList().

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_bedrock(), chat_claude(), chat_cortex_analyst(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_gemini(), chat_github(), chat_groq(), chat_ollama(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Printing**:
#>   - *Tibble*: Shows a concise summary of the data, typically printing 
#> only the first 10 rows and as many columns as fit the screen. It 
#> suppresses row names by default.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Prints all rows and columns by default, which can be
#> overwhelming for large data sets.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting**:
#>   - *Tibble*: Returns another tibble when subsetting. If you use 
#> single brackets (`[ ]`), it will return a tibble. Double brackets (`[[
#> ]]`) can be used to extract specific vectors.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Subsetting can return vectors or data frames. It may
#> return a vector when a single column is accessed with single brackets.
#> 
#> - **Column Data Types**:
#>   - *Tibble*: Preserves types more consistently. Always keeps columns 
#> as the same data type, which can prevent unexpected conversions.
#>   - *Data Frame*: May simplify certain types, potentially converting 
#> row data types when subsetting or manipulation occurs.
#> 
#> - **Column Naming**:
#>   - *Tibble*: Allows for non-standard column names and this can 
#> include spaces and special characters.
#>   - *Data Frame*: More restrictive, standard data frames often require
#> syntactically valid names without special characters.
#> 
#> - **Class**:
#>   - *Tibble*: Is a modern implementation and subclass of a data frame.
#> It’s part of the `tibble` package in R.
#>   - *Data Frame*: The traditional data frame is a built-in R object 
#> with a strong historical basis in R.
#> 
#> - **Warning Messages**:
#>   - *Tibble*: Provides more informative warnings and error messages 
#> which are useful in debugging.
#>   - *Data Frame*: May not provide as detailed feedback for common data
#> frame mistakes or issues.
#> 
#> - **Data Handling**:
#>   - *Tibble*: Generally more robust in handling different data types 
#> without modification.
#>   - *Data Frame*: Can lead to unexpected behavior especially with 
#> factor levels and type conversions.
#> 
#> Both tibbles and data frames are used to store tabular data in R, but 
#> tibbles are often preferred in the tidyverse ecosystem for their 
#> user-friendly features and consistency.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statisticians")
#> Sure, here are three jokes about statisticians that might give you a 
#> chuckle:
#> 
#> 1. **Normal Distribution**:
#>    - Why don’t statisticians like to play hide and seek?
#>    - Because good luck finding them; they always tend to be with the 
#> mean!
#> 
#> 2. **Light Bulb**:
#>    - How many statisticians does it take to change a light bulb?
#>    - Just one—but they’ll need a more specific problem statement, data
#> on current and past light bulb usage, a hypothesis, a lighting plan 
#> with confidence intervals, and a review from their peers!
#> 
#> 3. **Finding Mean**:
#>    - What did the statistician say to a random sample?
#>    - "You're totally normal!"
